review.title: An investigation into the relationship between type-2 FOU size and environmental uncertainty in robotic control
review.abstract: It has been suggested that, when faced with large amounts of uncertainty in situations of automated control, type-2 fuzzy logic based controllers will out-perform the simpler type-1 varieties due to the latter lacking the flexibility to adapt accordingly. This paper aims to investigate this problem in detail in order to analyse when a type-2 controller will improve upon type-1 performance. A robotic sailing boat is subjected to several experiments in which the uncertainty and difficulty of the sailing problem is increased in order to observe the effects on measured performance. Improved performance is observed but not in every case. The size of the FOU is shown to be have a large effect on performance with potentially severe performance penalties for incorrectly sized footprints.
histories: 2012 IEEE International Conference on Fuzzy Systems (FUZZ-IEEE), pp 1-8, 2012
2012 IEEE International Conference on Fuzzy Systems (FUZZ-IEEE), pp 1-8, 2012
review.COMMENTS: 2012 IEEE International Conference on Fuzzy Systems (FUZZ-IEEE), pp 1-8, 2012

metadata.title: An Investigation into the Relationship Between Type-2 FOU Size and Environmental Uncertainty in Robotic Control

sections.text: Keywords: Type-2 fuzzy interval, robot boot control, fuzzy control, uncertaintyI. INTRODUCTIONA fuzzy logic system maps inputs in a fuzzy set using a fuzzifier. The fuzzy set output is then processed as part of a Fuzzy Inference System (FIS), where the set is used as input for an inference system and its associated rule base. This results in a new output set that can itself be decentralized into a value suitable for use as a standard (e.g. PID) controller output. The way in which the processing of the fuzzy sets is handled can be varied based on application-specific requirements or limitations, and this leads to three main subcategories of fuzzy control: Type-1, Interval Type-2 and general Type-2. In this paper we look at the type-1 and interval-type-2 based systems and apply both control problems to increasing levels of uncertainty.

sections.heading: II. BACKGROUND
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Type-1 Fuzzy Logic
sections.text: The type 1 fuzzy logic introduced by Zadeh in [15] uses 2D membership functions that are usually triangular or Gaussian in shape. The x-axis represents the amount of possible inputs into the system obtained from the application.The y-axis represents the degree to which the given input is a member of the fuzzy group and has a value between 0 (no membership in the group) and 1 (full membership in the group).One of the main deficiencies of the type 1 fuzzy logic is its limited flexibility. Moving a type 1 controller coordinated in a particular environment to another environment can often lead to significant performance deteriorations unless changes are made to the control.Mendel [3] has found that type 2 control can be advantageous in many areas over type 1, such as in robust control where the information to be processed is uncertain.

sections.heading: B. Type-2 Fuzzy Logic
sections.text: Type-2 fuzzy logic is a development of type-1, and with this development comes greater freedom and flexibility, as discussed by Wu [13]. This can increase performance in certain situations, as investigated by Hagras [2], to the potential cost of increased computing load. Part of the increased flexibility of this type of system can be attributed to the fact that the membership functions in type-2 systems are represented in three dimensions, rather than in the two type-1. This additional dimension leads to what is known as secondary membership functions at the 2D level. They are referred to as upper and lower membership functions (UMF and LMF) 8 July 201 3In an interval type-2 system, the value of the secondary function is binary, whereby interval type-2 systems can be represented by two individual membership functions at the 2D level. They are referred to as upper and lower membership functions (UMF and LMF).

sections.heading: III. EXPERIMENTAL METHODOLOGY
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Problem description
sections.text: The application to be used as a test case is FLOATS, described in [1]. It is an autonomous sailing boat, originally based on the work of Stelzer in [11] and capable of operating both in the simulation and in the real world. Wind, location, waypoint and direction sensors are used to calculate error and triangular error values, which are used as inputs for a fuzzy inference system that generates an output value for rudder changes. In this paper, we have opted for simulation as an experimental method, with real-life experiments planned for future work. The simulator used, tracksail, was used by others for the development and testing of autonomous sailing robot systems including sauce and neal [7]. Tracksail is a Java-based open source software and communicates with boat controllers using a standard network sock.A value set by this controller would be better reserved for all controllers in the H1 controller.

sections.heading: B. Hypothesis
sections.text: We anticipate that there will be a point at which the difficulty of the course is sufficient that the Type 2 will significantly improve the results of the standard Type 1 controller. We expect this behavior to occur more clearly in situations with a higher uncertainty value as described in Table II and with the additional turns that further exaggerate the effect. The uncertainty value is only used to give an arbitrary order for the configurations and is calculated from the sum of the direction and speed uncertainty values. It is expected that the RMSE will increase in a predictable manner as the various wind configurations are tested - with the A and B configurations having lower RMSE values than, for example, the H and I. We do not expect a linear increase, especially since several configurations have the same uncertainty value. We also expect that with the increase in the FOU size, performance will begin at Type 1 levels. We expect this to coincide with an overall performance increase as the FOU and a larger decrease ensues.

sections.heading: C. Experimental Design
sections.text: The controllers in the test maintained the same membership functions throughout all experiments, showing the Type 1 membership functions in 1 (a). The only change in each run was the horizontal movement of the Type 2 controller, which changes the size of the FOU. We tested six different values for each FOU size, starting at 0 and increasing up to a maximum of 25 in steps of 5. An example of FOU size 10 is shown in Figure 1 (b). In our application, we derive our Type 2 membership function by introducing a horizontal movement into the Type 1 membership functions, varying the amount of movement as a parameter value. Figures 1 (b) and 1 (c) show examples of this, shifting the Type 1 membership function 10 and 20 respectively, to give the shown VOU. Two separate mechanisms were used to gradually increase the difficulty of completing the course, with the aim of testing to highlight the differences in performance that may be achieved in the different systems.

sections.heading: D. Course Design
sections.text: Courses are built from the simplest of all the courses - a straight line with a parallel fixed wind, where the boat simply has to move forward to complete the course. Difficulty is then increased by adding turns with different angles, as shown in Figure 2. It is noted that the courses to be tested contain either one or two turns. Vertical movement required to complete the course, which is defined as either 0, 25, 50 or 100 meters, changes the angle that the boat has to rotate to complete the course. The angle required for the first round is 5.71, 11.42 and 21.84 for 25, 50 and 100 meters vertical movements, respectively, while the second round, which is twice as large, will be 11.4, 22.84 and 43.68 centimeters. Any combination of course layout and wind configurations as shown in Table II is tested with each controller configuration.

sections.heading: IV. RESULTS
sections.text: This year it has come to the point that it has never come as far as this year.

sections.heading: V. DISCUSSION
sections.text: In fact, the number of cases that we have seen in recent years is significantly higher than the number of cases that we have seen in recent years. (...) The number of cases that we have got a grip on is very high. (...) The number of cases that we have got a grip on is very high. (...) The number of cases that we have got a grip on is very high. (...) The number of cases that we have got a grip on is very high. (...) The number of cases that we have got a grip on is very high. (...) The number of cases that we have got a grip on is very high. (...) The number of cases that we have got a grip on is very high. "(...)

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSIONS & FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We have shown that type 2-based controllers can perform better than type 1 controllers. However, caution must be exercised when designing the type 2 system, especially with regard to the size of the FOU. Too small an FOU and type 2 FLC will not improve compared to type 1. Too large and it will perform worse. In our chosen application, a FOU size of 20 seems to be the optimal value over a range of experimental conditions. Further work is required to determine the reason for this value. Overall, this work shows that the relationship between performance change and ambient noise is much more complex than previously thought. The statement that increasing ambient noise will lead to an improvement in the performance of type 2 compared to type 1 is not supported by the results in this paper.

sections.heading: A. Future Work
sections.text: The next step in this work will be to conduct these experiments in a real environment and to observe to what extent the results presented here in the simulation are applicable to a problem of real control. Based on the results of these experiments, a generalized type-2 could be a pathway for future work.

sections.heading: VII. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: The authors thank the School of Computer Science, University of Nottingham for their support in funding this paper.

referenceMentions.context: The application discussed in this paper is one of robotic sailing using the FLOATs (Fuzzy Logic Operated AuTonomous Sailboat) platform as described in [1], in which a robotic sail boat actuates sail and rudder positions based on received sensor data with the aim of steering an autonomous boat around a predetermined course.
Similar boat based applications have been investigated with a variety of approaches such as PID [6], biologically inspired [8] and fuzzy methods as in [10].
Similar boat based applications have been investigated with a variety of approaches such as PID [6], biologically inspired [8] and fuzzy methods as in [10].
Similar boat based applications have been investigated with a variety of approaches such as PID [6], biologically inspired [8] and fuzzy methods as in [10].
Type-1 Fuzzy Logic Type-1 fuzzy logic, introduced by Zadeh in [15] uses 2D membership functions that are commonly triangular or Gaussian in shape.
It has been stated by Mendel [3] that type-2 control may be advantageous over type-1 in many areas such as robust control in which the information to be processed is uncertain.
Type-2 Fuzzy Logic Type-2 fuzzy logic is a development of type-1 and with this development comes greater freedom and flexibility as discussed by Wu [13].
This may increase performance in certain situations as explored by Hagras [2], at the potential cost of increased computational load.

With general type-2 fuzzy logic, unlike in interval systems, the secondary membership function is continuous instead of discrete, for a more comprehensive overview of type-2 fuzzy logic the reader is directed at a paper such as [4].

For example Wu [14] and Wagner and Hagras [12] both present distinct methods to reduce the computational load significantly so that is is manageable by resource constrained systems such as those used on mobile robots.

For example Wu [14] and Wagner and Hagras [12] both present distinct methods to reduce the computational load significantly so that is is manageable by resource constrained systems such as those used on mobile robots.
Problem description The application to be used as our test case is FLOATS, described in [1].
It is an autonomous sailing boat originally based on the work done by Stelzer in [11] which can work in both simulation and the real world environments.
The simulator used, Tracksail has been used by others for development and testing of autonomous sailing robot systems including Sauze and Neal [7].

Our results are supported by other works in which type-2 performance is compared with type-1 such as the work by Musikasuwan et al in [5] where a type-1 controller outperforms, albeit by a small margin, a type-2 based controller.

The size of the FOU is shown to be have a large effect on performance with potentially severe performance penalties for incorrectly sized footprints.
